Award.AwardTitle: SOLAR Collaborative: Designing and modeling advanced nanostructure based hybrid solar cells
Award.AbstractNarration:
TECHNICAL SUMMARY:
In this proposal, supported by the NSF CHE-DMR-DMS SOLAR Initiative, PIs describe their vision for new hybrid photovoltaic materials via nanoscale integration of organic and inorganic materials to exploit the unprecedented high extinction coefficient of conjugated polymers and high carrier mobility of the solid-state semiconductors. This study will address many fundamental questions pertinent to organic-inorganic hybrid solar cells that utilize nanoscale structures. Through unique world-class expertise in chemistry, materials, devices and mathematics, this project explores the effects of scale and structure as it applies to interface quality, material structure, energy transfer and electronic behavior. This work includes simultaneous study of polymer synthesis, polymer and nanostructure material as well as geometrical parameter optimization and spectroscopic study and device development. One of the compelling aspects of this work is the synthesis of polymers with complementary absorption and band offset to III-As and III-P inorganic semiconductors supported by mathematical calculations. In parallel, an in depth study will be conducted in the development of optimal nanostructure design for efficient light coupling, absorption and carrier extraction. A primary focus of this work will be on the roles of surface states, surface passivation and electronic coupling between organic semiconductors and inorganic nanostructures in hybrid solar cells. Intrinsic to PIs efforts will be state-of-the-art calculations on multiple conjugated polymer chains and surface passivation agents that will point the way toward enhancing carrier mobility and long-range energy transfer in these materials. Synthesis of new polymer materials to effectively pair with available III-V materials along with optimized nanostructure design will produce a new photovoltaic device fabric.
NON-TECHNICAL SUMMARY:
This program has been designed to include several targeted efforts to directly impact society through multidisciplinary, multi campus collaboration. At the core of this project is integrated research and education for students at all levels (K-12, undergraduate, graduate, postdoctorates). Through research involvement, summer workshops and campus exchange, this SOLAR program will generate highly skilled researchers and scientists. Direct outcomes of this project will be shared best practices in K-12 activities, a co-developed graduate course in solar cell development to emphasize organic synthesis/inorganic materials/modeling/analysis, URM student involvement in SOLAR research along with collectively strengthened industrial collaboration. In a more general sense, this research will provide fundamental understanding of the organic and inorganic material interfaces as well as electrical and optical properties of the hybrid solar cells. This study will broadly influence the basic design of future hybrid solar cells and their efficiency limits.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project was aimed at studying hybrid solar cells which combine the advantages of both organic polymers and inorganic nano structures. It was a joint project between the experimental group of Diana Huffaker and the theory group of Christian Ratsch (both at UCLA). The collaboration between theory and experiment was in an interactive feedback loop such that theory and experiment complemented and guided each other.

Hybrid solar cell can potentially utilize the high absorption cross section of organic polymers and the high carrier extraction efficiency of inorganic nano structures. Moreover, nanowires can increase light absorption via light trapping. In this project, we systematically investigated Gallium Arsenide (GaAs)/polymer hybrid solar cells in a simple planar junction to fundamentally understand the function of semiconducting polymers in GaAs/polymer-based heterojunction solar cells. Specifically, we investigated polymers such as P3HT, PEDOT, DTffBT etc. in combination with Gallium Arsenide (GaAs) nanowires. We showed that the photovoltaic behavior of a planar solar cell of GaAs with an ultrathin polymer layer (PEDOT:PSS) is noticeably affected by the surface orientation the GaAs layer. The lower density of surface states of the GaAs (111)B surface helps reduce the surface recombination and results in a higher short circuit current for (111)B based hybrid solar cells , compared to hybrid solar cells where the GaAs is in the (100) orientation. We also found that n-type GaAs forms a Schottky barrier with its corresponding anode, while the semiconducting polymer of appropriate energy levels can function as a hole transport layer and/or electron blocking layer. In order to understand the charge transfer across the organic and inorganic interface, we probed photo-induced charge transfer at a model interface between copper phthalocyanine (CuPc) and gallium arsenide (GaAs) by tracking the electric field on the femtosecond time scale using time-resolved second harmonic generation. 

As the nanowires have high surface areas, they are prone to carrier recombination at the surface and hence low energy conversion efficiency. To avoid such effects, surface passivation was investigated using sophisticated theory and experiments. In our initial study with surface passivation, it was found that ammonium sulfide coating on the nanowires substantially increases the solar cell performance. The theoretical part of our work illuminated the microscopic mechanisms that lead to an improved performance upon sulfur passivation. In-situ AlGaAs or InGaP passivation proved to be better than ex-situ ammonium sulfide passivation. We have demonstrated a GaAs core-shell nanowire solar cell with 7.43% efficiency by using InGaP in-situ passivation. Towards achieving hybrid solar cells, we have investigated various polymers such as P3HT, DTffBT and FTAZ in combination with GaAs nanowires. In the polymer solar cells studied, ultra thin polymer layers contribute very little to the photocurrent and most of the current is generated by nanowires.  However, it can be predicted that these polymers simply serve as hole transporting layers.

This project resulted in 9 peer reviewed journal publications and over 10 conference presentations. Four post doctoaral scholars and 5 graduate students were trained and partially suppo rted during this project in a highly interdisciplinary environment.
